>>1300222
If you're worried

Don't wear polyester, nylon, acrylic, etc clothing. If you have to wear them, never wash them, washing them releases far more microfibres than than the plastic funnel of a coffee dripper.

Also don't eat fish. You shouldn't be eating them for other reasons anyway.

And don't go near roads. Tyres spray the stuff into the air.

Don't walk on or sit on carpets or furniture made from any of the above listed synthetic fibres.

Never drink from a prepacked plastic drink bottle. Especially never drink from a paper cup. They're usually plastic coated to waterproof them.

Good luck living your plastic free life.

Unfortunately it's really difficult to find manga raws in high quality, even digital raws from Amazon can be mediocre. Your best bet for raws are usually manga-zip and nyaa.si.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299013
For example, if you run the script
>yt-dlp --download-archive archive.txt https://www.youtube.com/@bisnap/videos
then the program will (1) download all the videos on that page and (2) record all the IDs of the downloaded videos in the file archive.txt. If you run the same script again (e. g., through a daily cron job), then the program will skip downloading any videos whose IDs are already listed in archive.txt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299017
And, if you've already downloaded a bunch of videos prior to beginning to use the "download-archive" option, you can use the "dateafter" option to filter stuff that was uploaded before a certain date.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How do I enhance audio on a mp3 file in audacity? I am trying to help my family members win a lawsuit against a nursing home for medical malpractice and my mom sent me an audio file that she has asked me to edit so the conversations can be heard. (The recording was obtained in a 1 party consent state.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300085
Could you post a sample?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300085
Find the parts that are actual conversation. Make a note of where they are hh:mm:ss as a reminder

Find periods of silence, no talking, no rustling cloths, passing traffic, etc. Good if it's a few seconds long but even half a second can be useful. Select one of these sections.

Go to Effect | Noise Removal and Repair | Noise Reduction...
Click on Step 1 Get Noise Profile
The dialogue box will close.

Then select a bit of the speaking section.
Go to Effect | Noise Removal and Repair | Noise Reduction...
Play around with the settings in Step 2 and test.

Then amplify the section you're working on
Go to Effect | Volume and Compression | Amplify...
Play around some more and test.

Then once you're happy, undo all the changes, like by closing the file and starting a new project. This time, instead of select some of the speaking, Select All and apply Step 2 of noise reduction and amplification to the whole track.

Sometimes, it's better to amplify first, then do both steps of noise reduction.

If you noise reduce too much you can end up with problems, like making people sound like the bubbling sound used on kids shows for people underwater or other things. Too much amplification will clip the sound and distort it. So test until you're happy. You can amplify one section at a time if you like and if recording conditions change, like maybe inside to outside it can sometimes help to noise reduce each section separately with a noise profile from a nearby time.

>>1300085
>(The recording was obtained in a 1 party consent state.)
We have literally no way of verifying this and the problem would be yours if it wasn't true. It's an unnecessary detail.

Be prepared that the opposing litigant will contest the legitimacy of your editing of the recording and a judge or jury will listen to this contest. They'll attack your credentials, of which you have none, and they could easily accuse you of tampering because you have no professional standing or code of practice to uphold.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300089
I think you got the wrong thread/board.

Anyways, the problem isn't the conceptual design of a projectile-style physics package, anyone with an engineering degree could make one of those, the problem is enriching Uranium. You can do that in one of three ways:
- in a breeder reactor, the downside of which being you need to already have enriched uranium and a nuclear reactor
- in a Calutron, which is basically a factory-complex-sized mass-spectrometer. This is what was used in the Manhattan Project, and the whole process was so complicated and fascinating it's worth reading the whole thing: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calutron . Spoiler: they used 6,000 TONS of silver, because the war couldn't spare 6000 tons of copper
- centrifuging Uranium Tetrafluoride. This is how it's done nowadays. UTF is probably the worst chemical that can possibly exist, it's worth reading the Material Safety Data Sheet if you've got a thing for dark nerd humour. I particularly liked "Observe all Federal, State and local Regulations when disposing of this substance", given how it's controlled as a precursor to nuclear weapons, radioactive, poisonous (because of the uranium), poisonous (because of the fluorine), corrosive, carcinogenic, and borderline explosive.
https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2020/11/f80/SDS-Uranium_Hexafluoride_UF6_2020.pdf
You have to heat it until it's a gas, then centrifuge the gas. Heat it but don't let it catch fire, there's very few substances that will put it out. Water turns it into hydrofluoric acid, which will eat through your flesh, then react with your bones and turn your bones into poison. You need to do this with hundreds of tons of this stuff to get enough enriched uranium to make a gun-type warhead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300089
Yes, implosion-type warheads are much more efficient, but very few people know how to make one that works. You could probably add a tritium booster to a gun-type bomb reasonably easily though, which could get you somewhere between Little Boy and Fat Man in terms of yield (though you'd still be at Little Boy in terms of uranium requirements and size-of-package)

Aside, I thought the first episode of Tanya was shit, and didn't watch any further, but if you've got flying witches, how do you know atomic physics even works?

posts.sub: Looking for help to locate an early 2000's gaming magazine
posts.com:
Hey guys I would like your help in finding an issue of an early 2000's gaming magazine.

Things I remember about it:

-Had articles on Neo Geo Pocket Color games, 100% sure it had one on either of the NGPC Metal Slugs and some of the SNK fighters.
-I distinctly remember one of the articles was about reviewing Tiger Electronic type games of the time, one being the one in my OP image. The premise of the article was that a kid had asked his grandma for videogames and she got him a bunch of those electronic games. The article had photos of the kid and the grandma, actually two guys in costumes, the guy playing the kid was kneeling to look short and had one of those propeller hats. Grandma of course looked like an obvious hairy guy in drag.
-This last one I'm not sure, probably was a different magazine altogether. In any case I remember an import article on pokemon gold and silver, overviews of the cities and routes in particular. I say import because they were still using the japanese names for the cities and pokemon. Probably even had a list with images of all the new Pokemon but I can't recall.
-Perhaps it was a dedicated handheld console magazine? Or a special issue on portable consoles?
-Had some ads for games published by 3DO. I'm almost positive there was one for the GBC Battletanx.
-Based on this info I remember, it has to be from around late 1999 to mid 2001 most likely.

I would appreciate any help

posts.sub: Motherboard no longer recognizing M.2 Boot drive(s)
posts.com:
I built a new system a bit over a month ago with the MSI PRO Z690-A DDR4, and i've been using it since as a daily driver. Yesterday i had a system crash (didn't even go to BSOD, just froze and shut down) and since then i've been having a hell of a time booting up. It seems the motherboard is failing to boot from the m.2 slot. At first i naturally suspected that it was the drive that was faulty (Samsung SSD 980 PRO 2TB) but since i had my old computer around i put the new drive in the old computer and it was detecting it (and booting) up just fine, so my suspicions kinda shifted to the Mobo. Additionally, the old drive in the new computer is also detected but won't boot either. Most of the times the BIOS will show that no drives are connected (i just have the one m.2 slot filled, no sata ssds or hdds), from time to time, the drive will apear but the computer will still go straight to bios, no booting, even when recognizing the M.2 drive. I have updated the BIOS, to see if that made any difference, but it didn't. (Not sure i updated it much since i had already updated the BIOS when building the system, i'm using a 13600k CPU).

HOWEVER, and this is where it gets super weird for me, yesterday night it booted up just fine, i could fuck around, play my videogames and be happy again, i thought the problem had been a hiccup and it was solved. But i was wrong, we're back to square one this morning, so i come to y'all for any help/advie you can offer.

I guess i could try resetting the cmos and updating the bios again? Not sure if that would make a difference or not, my tech expertise is relatively limited, i build systems for friends and myself and they usually work, this is uncharted territory for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How and from where do i start learning game development? How do you do it efficiently and how long can it take to get decent results?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You should start by defining "decent results"

Ideally you know how to program, and if not, you'll either have to learn at the same time as you learn game development, or else try to learn the basics of programming before you start learning game development. It's ideal to already know programming because it's going to be that much harder for you to grasp new concepts and design your own robust systems if you don't even know what a function is. If you already know some programming and have worked on some projects in the past then you already have a pretty big leg up

Unity has a lot of tutorials, like A LOT a lot, some of them good and some of them... well some of them just tell you to download plugins from the asset store, which hurts you more than helps you in the long run. If you chose to start with Unity, I recommend Ruby's 2D Adventure: https://learn.unity.com/project/ruby-s-2d-rpg
Because it's a small tutorial with easy to grasp concepts. Don't worry if you'd prefer to make 3D games, because it will give you enough to learn the basics of the engine and go your own way. There are a lot of 3D tutorials also.

If you don't want to use Unity then I don't know, I'm sure there are decent learning materials for other engines too. If you're especially cool and want to learn games programming "the spartan way" there is something called Raylib, which I really enjoy but is admittedly not for everyone: https://www.raylib.com/

Ultimately games development is about what you're willing to put into it and you have to be in it for life basically lol. It will take a lot out of you so you have to really want it unless you're content with making dumb little game jam demos. Approach it with a learner's mindset because you're always going to be learning new things even after your 3rd or 4th game release. There's just so much to learn, and halfway through every project, you're going to feel like dropping that project because you'll know that there's a better way to design it.

I have a problem downloading apps and games because what might be a storage bug(?)

The phone says I still have 6gb left out of 64 but I can't download apps more than around 3gb, but if it's less than that I can download them and it'll fill the storage. One game says not enogh storage even though it's only 4gb. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299884
>I can't download apps more than around 3gb
That's because it has to:
- download the app (3gb)
- extract the app (another 3gb)
- then delete the download (minus 3gb)

So you need 6gb to download a 3gb app, 8gb to download a 4gb app, and so on.

Try "preconversion from" "UTF-8".

It's pretty common to see shift-JIS (which is basically unicode-before-unicode) encoded as UTF8 when you extract a zip or similar.

i.e. you have UTF8_encode(shift_JIS_encode(<codepoints>)) but what you want is UTF8_encode(<codepoints>), so you have to un-UTF8 it, then translate it from shift-JIS to UTF8.

to answer your question, the easiest way would be to either use the traffic monitor built in to your router if one exists or, failing that, to use an inbetweener device like a pihole or a homemade router and capture the traffic that way.

unless canon owns their own IP block there's no reliable way to figure out what IP range they're using and in fact they probably use multiple ranges including those of third party services like AWS or cloudflare.

i do not personally think it is worth the effort to bother with this, as even if you opted in to literally everything they could possibly collect, it's not going to include the contents of your documents so at most they'd probably have a rough profile of what kind of device you have and roughly where you are geographically. but you do you.
